content: There arent enough tests for the '.' ending the code for reverse.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good puzzle, perfect fit for CoC. Creator listened to feedback, issues with it have been fixed.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Love the idea of an acrostic clash of code!

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: My kid was learning the concept of acrostic in class and i found the idea for a clash of code superb !
Acrostic is a good idea for a clash of code !i love the idea ;)

Thanks again for all your comments and testing.
I've limited the number of input lines to 16 now, so no uncompilable "forever" :-)
Got the same Problem as Kohly for Java. "Forever" is not defined.

I cant solve it.

NameError: name 'forever' is not defined
at Answer.py. in <module> on line 9

I find this confusing :  empty lines (pure white-space)
as I don't know if it's means not character at all or only white spaces
This clash seems ok for me now

Thanks for your comments everyone.
I've simplified the description text, and removed multiple lines of whitespace.
I've kept the trailing input after the final "." -- there has to be something more than this I feel:
  print(''.join((a.rstrip()+' ')[0] for a in open(0)))

perhaps too much details for a clash. 

'trailing garbage' at the end feel  too dirty

I didn't downvote. Don't care about clashes.

Normally i wouldn't bother, but someone linked this in chat. Here's my take:
Rephrase the statement. There's a HUGE chunk of text in that statement that is completely irrelevant.

All you have to do is read input lines until you get a single dot. Take first character from each input line and print it as string.

What's the big chunk of text for?

I didn't downvote, but I don't think it makes sense to force robustness on code that has to be scrapped together in a few minutes. I like the blank lines as spaces, but only ever one. And I like this simple idea for a Reverse, as it's easy to guess even from multiword examples.

Please give reasons for any down-votes, otherwise I cannot improve the puzzle :-(

I added the note: "This puzzle will test your ability to code robustly and be liberal in what you accept.".  I think this is a good point, as it seems simple at first glance, but there are corner-cases that can catch you out.

Maybe it's already been done? Sorry, don't know, and that does seem wrong.
Edit: No nevermind, Clash of Code isn't rejected if they're accidentally similar to existing ones.
Thank you for approving my puzzle Romuald_78, my kid approved of it, but he has not got voting rights yet.
Thank you Smelty.
Thanks for your feedback and vote of confidence - it means a lot.
